entry.et: Middle English colonie, from Middle French & Latin; Middle French, from Latin colonia, from colonus farmer, colonist, from colere to cultivate wheel

def.dt: :a body of people living in a new territory but retaining ties with the parent state
:the territory inhabited by such a body
:a distinguishable localized population within a species a colony of termites
:a circumscribed mass of microorganisms usually growing in or on a solid medium
:the aggregation of zooids of a compound animal
:a group of individuals or things with common characteristics or interests situated in close association an artist colony
:the section occupied by such a group
:a group of persons institutionalized away from others a leper colony a penal colony
:the land or buildings occupied by such a group
:any of several glycoproteins that promote the differentiation of stem cells especially into blood granulocytes and macrophages and that stimulate their proliferation into colonies in culture
:a British colony over which the Crown retains some control
former province S Republic of South Africa ✽ Cape Town area 278,465 square miles (724,009 square kilometers)
